title: The Lost Lionesses : Forgotten English teenagers defied sexist yobs shouting  get your t *** out  to play in the first women world cup
body_text:
The Lost Lionesses: Forgotten English teenagers defied sexist yobs shouting 'get your t*** out' to play in the first women's world cup
Lionesses like Lucy Bronze, Mary Earps and Chloe Kelly became mega stars when they achieved Euros glory by beating Germany at Wembley in 2022.
But while our current squad are household names - it could not have been more different for the young women who represented England at their first major tournament nearly 60 years ago.
The first women's world cup was held in Mexico from August - September 1971, 20 years before the first official FIFA women's world cup would take place.
Refusal by the Football Association to sanction the forgotten Lionesses' trip in 1971 meant the team were obliged to call themselves the British Independents instead of England - though everyone in Mexico referred to them as England or 'Las Chicas de Carnaby Street'.
Jan Emms, who was part of that historic England team, remembers most of the players had part-time jobs and when they did play at home there were no roaring crowds.
She said: 'We were used to playing in front of one man and a dog, and the man was usually shouting 'get your t*** out' at us. And here we were playing in front of 90,000 people.
'Walking out on to that pitch, hearing the noise, seeing the size of that crowd, will live with me forever.'
Members of the team managed by Harry Batt, which has recently returned from Sicily, where they qualified for the finals of the 1971 Women's World Cup in Mexico
The England women's football team pose under a welcome sign outside their hotel in Mexico City during the Women's World Cup in Mexico, 18th August 1971
Members of the England women's football team dancing at their hotel in Mexico City during the Women's World Cup in Mexico, 18th August 1971
Jan Emms - a 'lost Lioness' poses with a football over 50 years after she represented England in the Women's World Cup
Jan's daughter' Gail Emms, who won a silver medal in Badminton at the Athens, has now written a book on the team's forgotten history called the Lost Lionesses.
In the book Jan recalls her childhood playing football in 1960s Bedford - at a time when the sport was determinedly not for girls.
There was a countrywide ban on women playing on Football Association-affiliated pitches but this did not stop Jan from playing on the streets with her brothers and other local footy enthusiasts.
Jan was spotted at the age of 17 by businessman Harry Batt who asked her to play for his team the Chiltern Valley Ladies.
Batt saw huge potential in women's football though he was somewhat alone in his vision.
Gail told the Telegraph: 'There were pockets of women's football round the country, usually where some enterprising dad had started things so his daughter could play.
'There was a team in Nuneaton, and one in Birmingham. There were no leagues or cups. So games were few and far between.'
Batt decided to seize the opportunity when he heard that a Women's World Cup was in the works.
Leah Williamson and Millie Bright of England lift the UEFA Women's EURO 2022 Trophy after their side's victory during the UEFA Women's Euro 2022 final
England's Lionesses go wild with their staff as they celebrate the country's first major title since 1966
The eager manager pressed the FA hard to try and secure their backing but unfortunately the men in charge were not interested in women's football.
Despite the early set-back, the players went ahead anyway and Batt assembled a team - largely made up of his Chiltern Valley Players - who travelled to Sicily for the qualifying tournament.
Jan recalled she had never been abroad before and so her father had to drive her to Peterborough to get a passport.
The English girls qualified for the finals in Mexico despite the challenges and having had limited big-game experience.
Another hurdle was soon thrown in the way as many players were required to give up their jobs in order to compete.
Therefore Batt resolved he would pick several young girls who would be able to travel in the school holidays - meaning the 14 who flew out to Mexico were all strikingly young.
Gail who is a retired olympic English badminton player has written a book called 'The Lost Lionesses' which is about her mother being part of the 1971 Women's football team
'Lost Lionesses' is a name retroactively applied to the first women's football team to represent England at a major international tournament, the 1971 Women's World Cup in Mexico
Being unofficial, unrecognised, and disbanded shortly after their return to England, the team was largely overlooked for nearly 50 years
The Lost Lionesses were mostly ignored by the media bar a small piece that appeared in the local paper
Jan was the third oldest, at 19 years of age.
She said: 'We had buses with police escorts, we had wonderful food, we stayed in the same hotel in Mexico City the England [men's] team had done at the World Cup the previous year.
'One of the girls found out from the staff she was in the room Bobby Charlton had been in. I never found out who'd been in my room. Knowing my luck, it was probably Peter Bonetti.'
There were five other teams who had made it through to the finals - from Argentina, the Netherlands, Denmark, Italy and the hosts.
A lack of experience meant the English first found themselves challenged by Argentina at the Azteca Stadium.
It was the match against the hosts that truly stunned Jan - as 90,000 spectators turned out to watch the game.
Manager Harry Batt with the team he took to Sicily, where they qualified for the finals of the 1971 Women's World Cup in Mexico
The tournament was organised by the Federation of Independent European Female Football (FIEFF) and Batt's unofficial team were known as the British Independents
Standing, left to right: Harry Batt (manager), Gill Sayell, Jean Breckon, Jan Barton, Jill Stockley, Carol Wilson (captain), Trudy McCaffery, Yvonne Farr, Lilian Harris (goalkeeper), Louise Cross, Marlene Collins, Val Cheshire and June Batt (assistant manager). Front row: Keith Batt (team mascot), Chris Lockwood, Leah Caleb, Paula Rayner and Pat Dunn (coach). Carol Wilson and Yvonne Farr both have a leg in plaster after being injured on the pitch
Left to right: Bobbie Wing, Paula Rayner, Carol Wilson (captain), Jill Stockley, Jan Barton, Leah Caleb, Louise Cross, Chris Lockwood, Jean Breckon, Trudy McCaffery and Val Cheshire. All but Wing were in the squad that competed in Mexico
The team unfortunately lost 4-0 and the were subsequently evicted in the group stage.
A fifth-place play-off against France also saw a loss for the British Independents despite Jan scoring twice in the game.
Denmark emerged as overall cup champions after beating Mexico in a game that was watched by 114,000 spectators - still the largest ever crowd to watch a women's match.
The forgotten Lionesses were mostly ignored by the media bar a small piece in the local paper.
But the events of 1971 may have had wider repercussions than could be imagined as the FA sanctioned the first ever England women's international the following year, against Scotland.
Jan said she and her team mates were not invited to even trial for the team and Harry Batt was banned for life from any involvement in football - which 'broke him'.
Most of the squad gave up on football and Jan does not have her medal anymore as it was stolen in a pub reunion.
- The Lost Lionesses by Gail Emms, published by Headline, is available now.
